title: Monday, 5th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hey, hello, hi. Welcome to Monday.

BE

Paul's just arrived, moaning about trains.

BE

He'll be logging in shortly, I'm sure.

11:04 am
BE

Have a portrait.

BE

https://twitter.com/arusbridger/status/772042163672715264

That's from the Weekend FT shindig in Hampstead on Saturday.

11:04 am

Which I missed, due to stuff, but I hear it was fun.

BE

Rainy, but fun.

PM

Only properly rainy at the end

11:05 am

There were some great sessions

Needed more food vans tho -- and an inside drinking venue. Both of which I think will be fixed for next year

BE

Good.

11:06 am
undefined
BE

So ...... We can start with the market, which is a bit dull due to US being off etc .....

BE

.... or we can start somewhere more interesting.

11:07 am
PM

...

BE

We've only about six readers at the moment, so I'm a bit cautious about being too "interesting" to an audience that might be classed as select.

BE

Perhaps some arbs can nudge their neighbours to tune in for the next few minutes, just so we avoid that accusation.

11:08 am
BE

So anyway ......

BE

GKN.

BE

Interesting weekend press.

11:09 am
BE

Sunday Times, for instance

BE

http://www.telegra...pension-gap-grows/

BE

GKN shares took flight as traders bet on rumours of a Chinese bid for the aerospace and car parts giant, ending up 6% at 328.8p. That seems unlikely, given its £2.1bn pensions deficit.

11:09 am
BE

Could it have its own deal in the making instead? GKN must propel its Driveline business into the fast-growing world of electric cars. There are deals to be had: Fiatmaker FCA is selling its Magneti Marelli parts business. But GKN has poked under that bonnet and is looking farther east. A deal in China's booming auto industry might be a good place to start.

BE

"unlikely"

BE

And SunTel ...

11:09 am
BE

The pension deficit has become a millstone for GKN, and is understood to have deterred potential buyers amid speculation that a succession of overseas suitors have been circling the company.
The turnaround specialist Melrose considered a bid earlier this year, City sources said, but instead opted to acquire an American air conditioning business.

BE

A major GKN shareholder said: “If there is a buyer out there, it would have to be someone like Melrose.
“The combination of aerospace and automotive makes it a difficult fit for trade buyers and the Chinese would have real problems with US regulators because of the defence contracts.”

BE

http://www.telegra...pension-gap-grows/

11:10 am
BE

All of which is useful, right? Useful context.

BE

Mostly context we've written already, over the past month, but I guess it focuses the mind.

BE

Nevertheless, let's see if we can add something on top of all this Sunday usefulness.

11:10 am
BE

There's a specific rumour on GKN

BE

Around which we need to use the RAW disclaimer.

BE

The rumour is that SAIC Motor Corporation of China has been preparing an offer.

11:11 am
BE

Initial premium of ~40% mentioned, which'd put it into the 450p ballpark.

BE

To emphasis, our understanding here is that GKN has not received an approach

BE

And SAIC is not a new name to attach to this rumour. We mentioned it here last month: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4JNDiHEAl

11:11 am
BE

And again here: http://ftalphavill...tslive/2016-08-30/

BE

Then chickened out of writing it for a third time here: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz4JNDiHEAl

BE

What we can add today is specificness. Specificity.

11:12 am
BE

We can add that SIAC, according to usually well-informed types, recently moved into late stages of preparing an approach.

BE

I've also heard SIAC's being advised by JP Morgan out of the US.

BE

Note -- the US is on holiday today, of course, which makes it tough to get some feedback.

11:12 am
BE

So the usual caveats apply. Stuff changes. Things fall apart.

BE

Just because something was happening doesn't mean it's still happening.

BE

What's right then isn't always right now.

11:13 am
PM

hmm

PM

I mention all this, on the back of the weekend flannel, to get a potential buyer specifically named.

11:14 am

hehehe

lightbulb

Well there's the banks

PM

Deutsche have a sizeable note out today

11:19 am
PM

And you can see the effect

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 198.90, down 5.4 (-2.64%), High: 203.00, Low: 196.90, Volume: 8.63m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 59.55, down 1.4 (-2.29%), High: 60.97, Low: 59.29, Volume: 70.80m
11:19 am
PM

They're looking at the longer term impact of near zero interest rates

PM

As well as the near term

PM

Let me share the cover sheet

11:20 am
PM

Navigating the sector from here

UK bank shares have been particularly volatile since the UK voted to leave the EU (announced on 24/6/2016): at one point RBS, Barclays & Lloyds were down 30-40% since pre-Brexit levels. However, almost all are at their highest point today since the announcement, buoyed by better-than-expected economic data and statistics (house prices grew in August according to Nationwide). This note takes a fresh look at the sector post-BoE rate cut and TFS introduction, looking at near-term, medium term and long-term effects. Overall we think that the lower-for-longer environment is clearly negative for sector in the long-term, but has differing impacts on individual banks in the near/medium term.

PM

Certainly have been volatile

PM

Lower for longer and its consequences for UK banks

11:20 am
PM

There is much uncertainty and debate about the potential impact of Brexit for UK & the EU. However, we think one thing that is clear is that the effects of lower interest rates for the UK banking sector are unlikely to be radically different to those in Eurozone. In the near-term deposit pricing is likely to compress further and faster (due to higher proportion of floating deposits vs assets). However, once this near-term liability benefit passes, we expect to see steady asset pricing pressure (new mortgage pricing remains 50bps below back book), with negative consequences for NII & profitability. To offset these effects sustainably in the long-term, UK banks will need to drive additional volume (risking further price compression), cut costs (further cost plans & charges likely) or improve non-interest income (at present UK is below EZ avg).

PM

Implications for individual banks and ratings

PM

RBS: TP to 170p, d/g to Sell: We think RBS is most at risk in near/medium term due already low deposit rates (36bps), likely downgrades to loan growth, additional restructuring charges & likely lack of dividend until 2018.
Lloyds: TP to 59p (d/g to Hold): Lloyds should benefit in near term from falling deposit costs and potential sub-debt redemptions. However, we see risks from remortgage churn in medium/longer term.
Barclays: TP rises to 176p (Hold): potentially more impacted in near term (due to low deposit costs and higher proportion of trackers mortgages). But benefits from i-bank / payments revenue diversification. Debt/pref repurchases may help earnings, though further issuance likely to dilute this.
Aldermore: TP rises to 188p (u/g to Buy): of banks we cover, stands the most to gain from the rate cut & TFS crowd-out effect we believe. Deposit costs were 181bps in 1H16: 5x the level of RBS. Falling liability costs should help offset asset pricing compression over the next 2 years.
HSBC: (Hold, TP 525p, u/c): see our special report on HSBC’s ‘Capital Map’.
Standard Chartered: (Sell, TP 479p, u/c): please see our separate note here .

11:21 am
PM

Valuation and risks

We use a combination of SoTP and DDM to value UK banks: please see individual company sections for more details. Key upside risks for the sector include better than expected economic performance, loan growth, margin resilience, and better-than-expected outcomes on regulation. Key downside risks include: margin pressure, lower growth, higher cost of risk, regulatory change, greater litigation conduct restructuring charges than forecast.

PM

Outright sell on Standarad Chartered

PM

Standard

11:22 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 655.70, down 5.7 (-0.86%), High: 661.80, Low: 651.90, Volume: 2.24m
PM

Here's a couple of pars from that separate note

PM

2Q16 results were an 11% miss to us as at the management adjusted PBT
level. Income was 2% better (though mix arguably weaker), costs 5% lower,
driving a pre-provision beat, but loan and other impairment was higher than
expected, with a loss from associates. Despite a better performance in 1H16,
costs are expected to rise in 2H16, and we think the revenue outlook for SC
remains challenging. The RoE target has been pushed out beyond 2018, but to
hit this still requires a material increase in revenues or significantly below-trend
impairments. SC trades at 0.7x 2016 TNAV, 11.6x 2018 EPS for a RoTE of 5.7%
in 2018 with limited dividend support. We retain our Sell rating.

11:22 am
PM

Revenues remain the key to future ROE
The decline in Standard Chartered’s revenues as it has de-risked and
repositioned over the past 2-3 years has led to a period of painful negative
operating leverage. Whilst good progress is being made on costs, and
impairments will normalize over time, we remain of the opinion that restoring
positive revenue momentum is key to the group making its cost of capital on a
3-5 year view. Here we think evidence in Q2 remains mixed, whilst revenues
did at least increase QoQ some of the bigger swings vs Q1 were relatively low
quality in nature (e.g. lower Principal Finance write-downs and “Other”).
Maintaining top-line momentum into what is normally a seasonally weaker H2
is also likely to be a challenge given the current interest rate & volume outlook
in many of the group’s bigger markets.

PM

Valuation & Risks, TP to 479p, retain Sell.
Overall adjusted earnings fall in 2016 are unchanged in 2017 and fall slightly in
2018. Costs are lower, but revenues have been lowered in 2017/18 (reflecting
environment). BVPS is higher on lower share dilution than expected during
1H16. This leaves Standard Chartered trading at 0.7x 2016 TNAV for an RoE of
5% in 2018 and limited near-term dividend support. We use a Dividend
Discount Model incorporating a Gordon Growth model to value Standard
Chartered. We forecast the bank to make a group RoTE of 6% in 2018 and we
assume a cost of equity of 10% and a growth rate of 0%. Our TP rises
modestly from 474p to 479p. We reiterate our ‘Sell’ rating. We think operating
leverage for SC remains challenging and see pressures on revenues in the
coming years. Upside risks: better capital formation, bid for SC, or significant
improvement in EM growth & commodity price prospects leading to improved
impairment & revenue outlook, fall in sterling should benefit the London-listed
share price given US$ earnings base.

PM

David Lock the lead analyst there

BE

BE

BE

11:26 am
BE

Soccer references don’t come naturally to this writer. But, on this occasion, the informal construction of football pundits used to assess teams’ capacity to recover from a setback – bouncebackability – also seems apt for UK economics commentators in the Brexit aftermath. The latest news from the Markit/CIPS PMIs suggests, when viewed in isolation, bouncebackability is an attribute of the UK economy. These business surveys dived in the first month after the referendum by registering the largest one-month fall ever seen on the Composite measure, but have recovered across the board in August. The Composite indicator is up to 53.6 versus 47.6 last month and 52.4 compared to the month before the referendum. As Exhibit 4 shows, the recovery has been broad-based for Manufacturing and Services at least.

BE

There is of course a real risk that the tendency for accentuated perspectives on what Brexit will mean for the economy has translated into some overly sensitive reactions in these important business activity and confidence surveys. In reality, it is unlikely either that actual output fell as sharply as the PMIs indicated in July or that it recovered as markedly in August. This post-referendum situation makes it very difficult to be confident about how the PMI-based GDP indicator will perform in Q3. For what it’s worth though, our indicator puts Q3 GDP at -0.1% q/q (Exhibit 1), in line with the forecast we’ve had since late June.

The PMIs are very timely indicators of business activity levels, but they are just indicators. The lags involved in the publication of actual output data mean that it is still very early days when it comes to assessing the Brexit reaction of the economy. Although we’ve had retail sales data for July it is only this week when we start to get more insight with July industrial production and construction output data. It won’t be until 30 September before we see how the services sector performed in the first month after the vote, never mind subsequently.

BE

This means the MPC is likely to use the September meeting to take stock of the early stage of implementation of its August policy actions rather than act to alter the stance of monetary policy – in either direction – at this stage. It will be a long time yet before we are able to gauge the economic reaction to the Brexit vote, but over the next few months, watch out for the squeeze on real spending power as inflation continues rise. The recovery in the PMIs is welcome but bouncebackability doesn’t mean going from the relegation zone to promotion in one go – and it’s unlikely that the UK economy is or has been at either of these metaphorical extremes since the referendum result.

11:26 am
BE

Or BNP ......

BE

All three sector PMIs beat market expectations by a large margin in August, having disappointed significantly the month before. The composite PMI consequently fell by a record amount in July only to rebound by a record amount in August. Such volatility makes it difficult to say with much certainty how the economy is performing in underlying terms; much will depend on September’s reading and whether it gives back any of the August bounce.

A flat-to-falling composite reading in September would leave the three-month-moving-average figure at a level broadly consistent with zero growth in Q3; Markit itself noted that the average thus far during the quarter points to stagnation. A further increase, however, would imply the potential for positive growth and also suggest a better outlook for Q4, as the economy would have ended Q3 with some momentum.

How business surveys develop from here will depend on many factors, but one will be the politics. One risk is that August’s surge in confidence was in part due to the political arena going quiet over the summer, after Mrs May had announced her cabinet; following a period political chaos, no news may have been taken as goods news. Now, however, the political debate over Brexit is beginning to ramp up again with tensions in the cabinet emerging in recent days and the US and Japanese interventions at the G20 making it clear that the UK still faces significant challenges in managing the Brexit process.

That said, while the process of Brexit and its ultimate impact remain unclear, one can probably say that recent data suggest that the worries in the run up to, and immediately after, the referendum that the economy would enter recession in the second half of 2016 look misplaced. Some of the near-term downside risks have dissipated, helped by stable markets and the Bank of England’s strong action to support the economy. Data are now consistent with stagnation or some possibility of modest growth in Q3.

BE

That -- or rather, sterling's strength -- accounts for most of the other FTSE movers. Imps and BAT and Vodafone and Diageo and etc.

Zoopla Property Group PLC (ZPLA:LSE): Last: 330.03, up 24.03 (+7.85%), High: 331.33, Low: 312.50, Volume: 267.86k
BE

Two reasons.

11:32 am
BE

First, uSwitch might be doing okay.

BE

(And anyone who wants a long chat about the sustainability of revenues for price comparison sites can probably find my email, incidentally. It's an area I don't really understand.)

BE

Second, there's the chance for management to set out its grand vision of moving from an estate agent's notice board to an all-encompassing housing portal.

11:34 am
BE

Here's the upshot of it.

BE

Ahead of the September 15 investor day, we are back on the horse and upgrading
Zoopla to Overweight from Equal Weight. Near term, we think current trading for
uSwitch is likely strong, leading to potential consensus upgrades. Beyond that, we see
several sources of upside – and we think that management’s vision (presented at the
investor day) will refocus attention on them. These are: 1) an attractive long-term
opportunity for uSwitch (our new market model presented in the note suggests the
energy switching market can increase 60% over 2016-20E and 2.5x in the medium
term), 2) why the recently acquired Property Software Group is attractive, and how it
positions Zoopla well as agents adapt to structural pressures (more in note), and 3)
the potential to drive synergies between the businesses in the portfolio, which the
market currently values at zero. The obvious pushback is the outlook for the property
portal business. In the event of a weaker UK property market we see a balancing act
between 1) potential for Onthemarket to crumble, 2) risks that agents could shift to
Rightmove only, and 3) the number of agents reducing. But our forecasts are
conservative, and our analysis of the underlying Property Services multiple suggests
caution is priced in. We upgrade our PT to 335p, with an upside case of 435p.

BE

Focus on current trading: With changing retail energy prices, the environment for
switching is good. Moneysupermarket’s Home Services division grew 53% in cal. Q2
despite no big collective switches and a comp of +31%. uSwitch should also benefit in 2H
(Sep YE). We model 20% growth in 2H. Company consensus has 4%. Even with extra
marketing, we are 4/8% ahead of consensus at group EBITDA in FY16/17E.

11:34 am
BE

Forecast changes: EPS goes up 3% in FY16E, 1% in FY17E and is unchanged in FY18E,
with higher uSwitch partly offset by more conservatism (again) on Property Services.

BE

Valuation: We now set our 335p PT (10% upside potential) on a SOTP with long-term
DCFs for each business. We have an upside case of 435p (greater than 40% upside), assuming higher forecasts at uSwitch (17p/share extra), some modest win back from Onthemarket (32p/share), £115m of synergy value from uSwitch (27p/share) and £80m of synergy value from PSG (19p/share). Our uSwitch valuation implies 18x 12m forward EBITDA (a 40% premium to Moneysupermarket), leaving Property Services on 15.5x. Our trading sum-of-the-parts analysis shows that vs Rightmove, the Property Services discount is now 33%, below its average of 14% and towards the low of 42%. Some caution is built in.

BE

Have to say -- Alex Chesterman has done a good job converting Zoopla's City image from being the Pepsi of property websites to being something more interesting.

Barclays Plc is close to naming JPMorgan Chase & Co.’s Tim Throsby to run the corporate and international division, including overseeing the investment bank, which will fill the final vacancy on Chief Executive Officer Jes Staley’s top management team, according to two people with knowledge of the talks. Barclays may announce the appointment over coming days, said one person, who asked not to be identified before the hire is finalized. Throsby, 50, joined JPMorgan in 2010 and was named global head of equities two years later, running the business from London.
